The museum can engage them through interactive sessions, in-depth talks, workshops, and meet-and-greet sessions with the author.

2. Book lovers: People who are fond of literature and enjoy reading books, especially art-related books. They attend author exhibitions or programs to explore the artist's work through the author's interpretations and analysis. Engagement for this group could include book signings, readings, and discussions.

3. Students and scholars: This group comprises students pursuing art, history, or literature courses or scholars researching art or artist in specific. They attend author exhibitions or programs as part of their curriculum or research work. The museum can engage them by organizing expert panels or Q&A sessions with the authors, providing access to archive material, and facilitating research opportunities.

4. Tourists: People who visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art as part of their travel itinerary. They are likely to attend author exhibitions or programs that coincide with their visit. The museum can engage them through guided tours, interactive workshops, and special exhibitions.

Overall, the Metropolitan Museum of Art can engage its audience groups by providing informative and engaging programs that cater to their interests and requirements. It can also leverage social media platforms to promote the events and create buzz.
